misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles for an unrelated problem instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program is written as an acceleration calculator that reads three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of reading five integers as required by the problem. It never attempts to obtain the 5 separate integer inputs for summing even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can reuse a program that reads v0, v1, and t as doubles for this task, and I only need those three inputs to solve the problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read exactly five integer values from the user (e.g., using nextInt) representing arbitrary integers, not physics quantities, in order to later sum only the even ones.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers
Three calls to nextDouble instead of repeated integer input
No use of nextInt or any structure to receive five numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused or adapted code for a different physics-style exercise and did not realign the input design with this problem’s requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the input section to read five integers (e.g., using int vars with input.nextInt() in a loop or five separate reads), and remove the v0, v1, t acceleration context.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly prompts for v0, v1, and t, uses nextDouble three times, and has no mention of five integers, which clearly contradicts the problem statement.

evidence.note: The code prompts for v0, v1, and t and reads three doubles, with no attempt to read five integers as required.

misconceptions.name: Implements acceleration formula instead of looping to sum even numbers
misconceptions.description: Rather than looping over five inputs to check for even numbers and accumulate their sum, the program computes an average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t and prints that result, which is unrelated to summing even integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: To solve the task, I should compute and print the average acceleration from v0, v1, and t using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program needs to iterate over five user-provided integers, use a conditional check to determine if each is even, accumulate the sum of those even numbers, and finally print that sum.
symptoms: No loop or repetition structure is present
No use of modulus (%) or any even-number check
Computes acceleration instead of a sum
Output message refers to average acceleration rather than sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a completely different exercise (average acceleration) rather than the required sum-of-evens problem, indicating a mismatch between the problem statement and the implemented algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the acceleration computation with a loop (for or while) that runs 5 times, reads an int each time, checks if it is even using n % 2 == 0, and if so adds it to a running sum which is then printed.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The core of main is devoted to computing (v1 - v0) / t and printing an acceleration message, with no looping, modulus, or sum variable, which clearly diverges from the required algorithm.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: The code calculates and prints average acceleration instead of looping to sum even integers.

misconceptions.name: Complete Task Mismatch: Submitted Code for Wrong Assignment
misconceptions.description: The submitted code calculates average acceleration from three input doubles (v0, v1, t) and does not address the required task of reading 5 integers and calculating the sum of the even numbers. None of the four required rubric components (reading 5 integers, loop, conditional check for even numbers, accumulating sum) are present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely submitted the wrong file or misinterpreted the assignment, believing they needed to solve a kinematics problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must be structured to specifically solve the 'Sum of Even Numbers' problem, involving iteration, integer input, conditional logic, and an accumulator.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration instead of a sum.
Input asks for physics variables (v0, v1, t) instead of generic integers.
Reads 3 double values instead of 5 integer values.
Absence of loop structure and conditional (if) statements.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a solution unrelated to the assignment prompt, resulting in a complete failure to meet all functional requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment description carefully and ensure the submitted source code addresses the correct programming problem (Sum of Even Numbers).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The class name, prompts, logic (v1-v0)/t, and variable usage all confirm the code is for a different, unrelated assignment.

evidence.note: Class name indicates a different program than 'Sum of Even Numbers'.
The input prompt asks for three physics variables, not 5 integers.
Reads 3 double values instead of 5 integer values. Also, there is no loop.
The logic calculates acceleration, not the accumulated sum of even numbers. There is no conditional check (n % 2 == 0).

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type for Input Variables
misconceptions.description: The required task involves working with integer variables. The student declares and reads floating-point numbers (`double`) for their input variables, which is incorrect for processing an array of integer inputs and determining parity.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student used the wrong primitive type (double) for the inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: If this were the correct assignment, the student should use `int` for the input variables and `input.nextInt()`.
symptoms: Use of 'double' keyword for input variables.
Use of 'input.nextDouble()'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misuse of primitive data types, likely carried over from the source material for the incorrect submission.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure variables holding counts or simple whole numbers are declared as 'int'.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly uses 'double' and 'nextDouble()' throughout the input reading.

evidence.note: Uses 'double' type and 'nextDouble()' instead of 'int' and 'nextInt()'.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: Student implemented a completely different program (acceleration calculator) instead of the required sum of even numbers program.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either misread the problem or submitted code for a different assignment entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers and summing only the even numbers. The student should implement a program that: (1) reads 5 integers, (2) checks each for evenness using modulo operator, (3) accumulates only even numbers, and (4) prints the sum.
symptoms: Program reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers
Program calculates acceleration formula (v1-v0)/t instead of sum of evens
Output is 'The average acceleration is...' instead of 'Sum of even numbers:...'
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No conditional check for even numbers
No accumulator for summing
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted incorrect assignment code or completely misunderstood the problem requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Read the problem statement carefully. You need to: create a loop that runs 5 times, read an integer each iteration, check if it's even using (n % 2 == 0), and add even numbers to a running sum. Print the final sum.
related_concepts: Input validation and reading multiple values
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the entire program logic, input requirements, output format, and purpose are completely different from the assignment specification. This is clearly a different problem.

evidence.note: Entire program calculates acceleration from 3 inputs, not sum of even numbers from 5 inputs

misconceptions.name: Reads 3 values instead of 5 integers
misconceptions.description: The program only reads three values (v0, v1, t) instead of reading five separate integers as required by the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: Reading three numeric inputs (v0, v1, t) from the user is sufficient, regardless of the problem’s requirement to read five integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly five integers from the user, typically using nextInt(), either in a loop or as five separate input operations.
symptoms: The code calls input.nextDouble() exactly three times.
There is no logic to read a total of five numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between this assignment and a different acceleration-calculation example or a misunderstanding of the required number of inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the input section to read five integer values (e.g., with nextInt()) and ensure all five are stored and processed.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt and variable names clearly reference an acceleration example, and the code reads exactly three doubles, which does not match the requirement to read five integers.

evidence.note: The program prompts for three values (v0, v1, t) and only reads three numbers, not five integers.

misconceptions.name: Uses double instead of int for required integer inputs
misconceptions.description: The student uses double variables and nextDouble() for user input, even though the task specifies reading integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is acceptable to treat the inputs as doubles when the problem asks for integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When the problem specifies integers, the program should use int variables and methods like nextInt() so the types match the requirement.
symptoms: All input variables (v0, v1, t) are declared as double.
Scanner calls use nextDouble() instead of nextInt().
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion or lack of attention to the distinction between integer and floating-point types in the problem specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change variable types for the five numbers to int and use nextInt() to read them.
related_concepts: Primitive data types in Java (int vs double)
Matching input types to problem specifications
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code consistently uses double and nextDouble() in a problem that explicitly requests integers, suggesting a misunderstanding rather than a one-off mistake.

evidence.note: All three inputs are read as doubles, conflicting with the requirement to read integers.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The code does not use any loop to handle multiple input values; it is written for a single calculation instead of iterating over five numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: A loop is not necessary; a single set of input statements and one calculation is sufficient.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To process five numbers systematically, a loop (such as a for loop that runs five times) should be used to read each value and update the sum.
symptoms: There is no for, while, or do-while loop in the program.
Only one calculation is performed using three values.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of the requirement to process multiple inputs or unfamiliarity with using loops for repeated input and accumulation.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for-loop that runs five times, reading one integer per iteration and updating an accumulator variable.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: No loop constructs appear in the code, despite the problem requiring processing of five numbers.

evidence.note: The main method contains only straight-line code to read three values; there is no loop structure to process five inputs.

misconceptions.name: Missing even-number conditional logic
misconceptions.description: The program does not check whether numbers are even using n % 2 == 0; it instead computes an acceleration formula unrelated to even-number filtering.
misconceptions.student_belief: No conditional is needed to distinguish even from odd numbers for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The code should use a conditional expression, such as if (n % 2 == 0), to include only even numbers in the sum.
symptoms: No modulo operator (%) appears in the program.
There is no if-statement that checks for evenness.
The only computation is (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented an entirely different problem (average acceleration) instead of the sum-of-evens problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Within the loop that reads each integer, add an if (n % 2 == 0) check before adding the value to the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The absence of any modulo or conditional logic, combined with an unrelated acceleration formula, strongly indicates the even-number check was not implemented.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: The only computation is an acceleration formula; no conditional or modulo operation is present to test for even numbers.

misconceptions.name: No sum accumulator for even numbers; prints unrelated result
misconceptions.description: Instead of accumulating a sum of even numbers and printing it, the program computes an average acceleration and prints that value.
misconceptions.student_belief: Computing and printing the average acceleration satisfies the requirement to output a result.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must maintain an accumulator variable (e.g., sum) that is updated only when an input is even, and then print 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by that sum.
symptoms: There is no integer sum variable or accumulator.
Output message refers to 'The average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'.
The result printed is based on (v1 - v0) / t, not on any sum of inputs.
misconceptions.root_cause: Student likely reused code from an average-acceleration example instead of implementing the required sum-of-evens logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an int sum = 0; update it inside the even-number check for each of the five integers, and finally print 'Sum of even numbers: ' + sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The variable names, formula, and output text all clearly relate to acceleration, not summing even numbers.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: The program computes an acceleration value and prints it; there is no sum accumulator or 'Sum of even numbers' output.
